title: 111_s1819
content:
The Act is known as the "International Civil Rights Center and Museum Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the establishment of the museum. The Congress finds that the Greensboro sit-in sparked nonviolent protests across the US, leading to over 70,000 participants in sit-ins by 1961. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum at the Woolworth's store site will preserve the civil rights movement's legacy for future generations. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum will open on February 1, 2010, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the sit-in movement. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins in commemoration of the opening of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, with specific design requirements including inscriptions of the year "2010" and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant entities, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may mint coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.

Sales of coins under this Act will include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges will be paid to the International Civil Rights Center and Museum for program development and research. The Comptroller General of the United States can audit the Museum's expenditures related to these payments.
